Articles: {"abstract": "Google struck a deal to invest about $5 million in one of the country\u2019s fastest-growing Internet start-ups, Xunlei.com.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2007/01/06/technology/06google.html", "snippet": "Google struck a deal to invest about $5 million in one of the country\u2019s fastest-growing Internet start-ups, Xunlei.com.", "lead_paragraph": "SHANGHAI, Jan. 5 \u0097 Like almost all of the American Internet giants that have ventured this far, Google is losing in China. {"abstract": "As with most things on Wall Street, last week\u2019s surge in Amazon.com\u2018s stock created some big winners and big losers. In the winners\u2019 column: Bill Miller, the mutual-fund manager from Legg Mason whose legendary 15-year streak of beating the S&P 500 ended last year when some of his value fund\u2019s top stock picks \u2014 including Amazon \u2014 failed to pay off. As recently as January, Mr. Miller doggedly defended his Amazon pick, writing in a letter to shareholders of his fund that \u201cinvestors wrongly believe today\u2019s low operating margins [at Amazon] are going to be the norm for years.\u201d ", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2007/04/30/amazon-giveth-and-taketh-away/", "snippet": "", "lead_paragraph": "As with most things on Wall Street, last week\u2019s surge in Amazon.com\u2018s stock created some big winners and big losers. [{"abstract": "Jason Kilar, the new chief executive of the joint venture between NBC Universal and the News Corporation to distribute video online, has one tough job.", "web_url": "https://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2007/06/28/from-amazon-to-hollywood/", "snippet": "Jason Kilar, the new chief executive of the joint venture between NBC Universal and the News Corporation to distribute video online, has one tough job.", "lead_paragraph": "I\u2019d say this is one unpleasant job description:", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "From Amazon to Hollywood", "kicker": "Bits", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [], "pub_date": "2007-06-29T00:52:08+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Technology", "byline": {"original": "By The New York Times", "person": [], "organization": "The New York Times"}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/1b05d413-6507-5ce6-8a00-6e8f424fd073", "word_count": 464, "uri": "nyt://article/1b05d413-6507-5ce6-8a00-6e8f424fd073"}, {"abstract": "YouTube is growing far faster than any other video site, creating a high bar for the new NBC-News Corporation video venture that Jason Kilar will run.", "web_url": "https://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2007/06/29/more-jason-kilar-challenges/", "snippet": "YouTube is growing far faster than any other video site, creating a high bar for the new NBC-News Corporation video venture that Jason Kilar will run.", "lead_paragraph": "Just to expand on Saul Hansell\u2019s explanation of the challenges facing Jason Kilar, the former Amazon exec who is slated to head the News Corporation and NBC Universal online video joint venture, consider this: Hitwise reported this week that YouTube\u2019s share of all visits to U.S. Web sites grew by 70 percent between January and May. This is traffic to the YouTube site only, not video streams or views of videos hosted on other sites. The share of visits to 64 other online video sites grew by only 8 percent during the same period, leaving YouTube with 50 percent greater market share than those 64 sites combined.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "More Jason Kilar Challenges", "kicker": "Bits", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [], "pub_date": "2007-06-29T17:50:19+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Technology", "byline": {"original": "By Miguel Helft", "person": [{"firstname": "Miguel", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Helft", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/7256278d-6457-5b67-af7e-a185cab950e0", "word_count": 133, "uri": "nyt://article/7256278d-6457-5b67-af7e-a185cab950e0"}]

As of this writing, Amazon\u2019s stock price is up more than 25 percent today after its second blockbuster quarterly earnings report in a row. [{"abstract": "Amazon\u2019s new Kindle reader costs $399 and can download books, newspapers and blog posts wirelessly.", "web_url": "https://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2007/11/19/amazon-pitches-a-wireless-ipod-for-books/", "snippet": "Amazon\u2019s new Kindle reader costs $399 and can download books, newspapers and blog posts wirelessly.", "lead_paragraph": "Amazon.com introduced its electronic book reader today at a packed event in New York. Unlike other products in this area, Amazon\u2019s $399 Kindle is designed to be used without ever connecting to a computer. Instead it has a wireless Internet connection that lets users browse Amazon\u2019s online store on the device and download a book in less than a minute.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Amazon Pitches a Wireless iPod for Books", "kicker": "Bits", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [], "pub_date": "2007-11-19T17:26:14+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Technology", "byline": {"original": "By Saul Hansell", "person": [{"firstname": "Saul", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Hansell", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/769de9f8-8511-5359-b699-7ba92c03cb7f", "word_count": 582, "uri": "nyt://article/769de9f8-8511-5359-b699-7ba92c03cb7f"}, {"abstract": "Potential future features that Jeff Bezos may add to his new e-book device, the Amazon Kindle.", "web_url": "https://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2007/11/19/enough-about-kindle-10-what-about-kindle-20/", "snippet": "Potential future features that Jeff Bezos may add to his new e-book device, the Amazon Kindle.", "lead_paragraph": "As Saul Hansell described below, Amazon is trying to awaken the slumbering electronic-book business with the Kindle, its long-awaited e-book reader and online service, which we first wrote about in September. {"abstract": "Now that Amazon\u2019s market value is nearly the same as eBay\u2019s, it could buy the online auction site. That could help improve Amazon\u2019s finances and eBay\u2019s customer satisfaction.", "web_url": "https://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2007/12/14/why-amazon-should-buy-ebay/", "snippet": "Now that Amazon\u2019s market value is nearly the same as eBay\u2019s, it could buy the online auction site. That could help improve Amazon\u2019s finances and eBay\u2019s customer satisfaction.", "lead_paragraph": "UPDATE: I posted two follow ups to this post. One is on the consumer frustration with eBay. The other is about the disillusionment of its sellers. ", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Why Amazon Should Buy eBay", "kicker": "Bits", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [], "pub_date": "2007-12-14T21:51:23+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Technology", "byline": {"original": "By Saul Hansell", "person": [{"firstname": "Saul", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Hansell", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/d0c51cc5-706e-5872-a6b4-2b58d736a34d", "word_count": 540, "uri": "nyt://article/d0c51cc5-706e-5872-a6b4-2b58d736a34d"}

[{"abstract": "After a post suggesting that Amazon buy eBay, Bits readers revolt with a litany of complaints about eBay. The site, they say, has such bad customer service and is so riddled with fraud that Amazon should stay away.", "web_url": "https://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2007/12/17/the-depth-of-ebays-problems-1-disappointed-buyers/", "snippet": "After a post suggesting that Amazon buy eBay, Bits readers revolt with a litany of complaints about eBay. The site, they say, has such bad customer service and is so riddled with fraud that Amazon should stay away.", "lead_paragraph": "I wrote a post Friday with the thought that Amazon should buy eBay, and readers nearly revolted at the idea. The outpouring of rage at eBay was of the sort we don\u2019t see here for anything other than cellphone companies. The company is clearly getting hit by both buyers and sellers. I\u2019ll write a post shortly on the frustrations of merchants on eBay.(UPDATE: That post is here.) Below is a sampling of the complaints from Bits readers.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "The Depth of eBay\u2019s Problems 1: Disappointed Buyers", "kicker": "Bits", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [], "pub_date": "2007-12-17T16:55:48+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Technology", "byline": {"original": "By Saul Hansell", "person": [{"firstname": "Saul", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Hansell", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/e14fd283-138f-5d46-a65b-7ffd18afaa2e", "word_count": 692, "uri": "nyt://article/e14fd283-138f-5d46-a65b-7ffd18afaa2e"}, {"abstract": "Sellers are defecting from eBay because its fees are high, customers are afraid of fraud, and merchants can do better on Amazon or on their own Web sites, attracting customers through Google.", "web_url": "https://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2007/12/17/the-depth-of-ebays-problems-2-angry-sellers/", "snippet": "Sellers are defecting from eBay because its fees are high, customers are afraid of fraud, and merchants can do better on Amazon or on their own Web sites, attracting customers through Google.", "lead_paragraph": "Here\u2019s another angle on what\u2019s wrong at eBay: Sellers increasingly find eBay\u2019s fees to be too expensive and are becoming successful at finding buyers on Amazon.com or on their own sites. I wrote Friday about why Amazon should buy eBay. And I posted this morning about the torrent of angry comments we got about eBay, mainly from buyers. ", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "The Depth of eBay\u2019s Problems 2: Angry Sellers", "kicker": "Bits", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [], "pub_date": "2007-12-17T21:08:29+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Technology", "byline": {"original": "By Saul Hansell", "person": [{"firstname": "Saul", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Hansell", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/7c16b540-aa86-5492-b47d-3fa04e1dad21", "word_count": 755, "uri": "nyt://article/7c16b540-aa86-5492-b47d-3fa04e1dad21"}]

{"abstract": "The Warner Music Group\u2019s announcement is the recording industry\u2019s latest move away from its reliance on digital locks to reduce piracy.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2007/12/28/technology/28music.html", "snippet": "The Warner Music Group\u2019s announcement is the recording industry\u2019s latest move away from its reliance on digital locks to reduce piracy.", "lead_paragraph": "LOS ANGELES \u0097 In the recording industry\u2019s latest move away from its reliance on digital locks to reduce piracy, the Warner Music Group said on Thursday that it would sell songs and albums without anticopying software through Amazon\u2019s fledgling digital music service.", "print_section": "C", "print_page": "7", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Amazon to Sell Warner Music Minus Copy Protection", "kicker": null, "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "Amazon to Sell Warner Music Minus Copy Protection", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Recordings and Downloads (Audio)", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "AMAZON.COM INC", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Warner Music Group", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Music", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Computers and the Internet", "rank": 5, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2007-12-28T05:00:00+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Technology", "byline": {"original": "By Jeff Leeds", "person": [{"firstname": "Jeff", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Leeds", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/7b0cfe24-18de-5775-bd58-7a6f560480ce", "word_count": 425, "uri": "nyt://article/7b0cfe24-18de-5775-bd58-7a6f560480ce"}

{"abstract": "Holiday traffic to Amazon.com surpassed traffic to eBay.com for the first time, according to Nielsen Online.", "web_url": "https://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/01/14/amazon-beat-ebay-in-holiday-traffic/", "snippet": "Holiday traffic to Amazon.com surpassed traffic to eBay.com for the first time, according to Nielsen Online.", "lead_paragraph": "For years, eBay ruled the e-commerce roost. Each holiday season, more visitors spent more time and looked at more pages on eBay.com than on any of its rivals, including Amazon.com. It made sense; eBay is a wide open forum for every kind of seller and item, while Amazon has traditionally pushed a selection of products through its network of physical warehouses.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Amazon Beat eBay in Holiday Traffic", "kicker": "Bits", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [], "pub_date": "2008-01-15T01:11:01+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Technology", "byline": {"original": "By Brad Stone", "person": [{"firstname": "Brad", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Stone", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/604d59b6-a2a6-5ccc-85e0-a074498b246d", "word_count": 376, "uri": "nyt://article/604d59b6-a2a6-5ccc-85e0-a074498b246d"}

{"abstract": "Meg Whitman is about to announce her retirement after a decade running eBay, a report says. The company faces challenges from Google and Amazon, and it may need to make more radical changes than has been the style of the cautious Ms. Whitman.", "web_url": "https://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/01/22/report-says-whitman-to-leave-after-conservative-decade-at-ebay/", "snippet": "Meg Whitman is about to announce her retirement after a decade running eBay, a report says. The company faces challenges from Google and Amazon, and it may need to make more radical changes than has been the style of the cautious Ms. Whitman.", "lead_paragraph": "The Wall Street Journal is reporting that Meg Whitman is retiring as chief executive of eBay. In March, Ms. Whitman, 51, will have served in the position for 10 years. {"abstract": "A federal appeals court has agreed to hear a patent case that may invalidate a controversial class of patents called business method patents, which seek to protect ways of doing business.", "web_url": "https://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/03/05/new-patentable-idea-a-way-to-invalidate-vague-patents/", "snippet": "A federal appeals court has agreed to hear a patent case that may invalidate a controversial class of patents called business method patents, which seek to protect ways of doing business.", "lead_paragraph": "There\u2019s not much love in legal circles for the so-called \u201cbusiness method\u201d patent, an exclusive intellectual property right over a novel way of doing business. {"abstract": "Pluspetrol, the Argentine energy company, has reopened an oil field in Peru\u2019s northeastern Amazon region as violent clashes between police and members of the local indigenous community subsided. The company said Block 1-AB in the Loreto department was operating normally. Pluspetrol had suspended operations at Block 1-AB, which accounts for most of Peru\u2019s oil output, on Thursday after protesters demanding higher salaries for local Pluspetrol workers stormed the installations. The clashes with police grew violent, and one officer was killed and five were wounded. {"abstract": "Assuming the success of the Kindle partly accounts for Amazon\u2019s crazy stock price, there may be a way to assess its value.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2009/01/09/business/09views.html", "snippet": "Assuming the success of the Kindle partly accounts for Amazon\u2019s crazy stock price, there may be a way to assess its value.", "lead_paragraph": "Amazon.com\u2019s hand-held electronic reading gadget, the Kindle, is selling like hot cakes. {"abstract": "A New York State court says Amazon.com and other online retailers must collect sales tax on purchases by New York residents.", "web_url": "https://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/01/13/court-to-amazon-keep-collecting-sales-tax-to-new-yorkers/", "snippet": "A New York State court says Amazon.com and other online retailers must collect sales tax on purchases by New York residents.", "lead_paragraph": "If you live in New York and shop at Amazon.com or other online stores, you are going to have to keep paying sales tax on what you buy. {"abstract": "Amazon\u2019s Universal Wish List button offers a way to let you remember the things you want to buy from other places.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2009/01/22/technology/personaltech/22askk-003.html", "snippet": "Amazon\u2019s Universal Wish List button offers a way to let you remember the things you want to buy from other places.", "lead_paragraph": "Even if you don\u2019t do all your online shopping in the virtual megamall that is Amazon.com, the site offers a way to let you remember the things you want to buy from other places. With a simple one-time drag-and-drop move, Amazon\u2019s Universal Wish List button, (available at www.amazon.com/gp/wishlist/get-button/), can be added to your browser\u2019s toolbar. The next time you are out shopping on other sites \u0097 but are not quite ready to buy \u0097 click the Wish List button on the browser to save a link to the item to your personal Amazon Wish List. Clicking on the item later on the Wish List takes you back to the original store when you\u2019re ready to get out the credit card.", "print_section": "B", "print_page": "2", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Tip of the Week: Online Shopping Wish List", "kicker": "Q & A", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Computers and the Internet", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "AMAZON.COM INC", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "RETAIL STORES AND TRADE", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2009-01-21T21:56:09+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Technology", "subsection_name": "Personal Tech", "byline": {"original": "By J .D. [{"abstract": "A Web site where people can submit reviews of prostitutes says it has severed ties with its founder, who has been charged with conspiracy to commit aggravated assault.", "web_url": "https://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/03/04/prostitution-site-cuts-ties-with-founder-after-charges/", "snippet": "A Web site where people can submit reviews of prostitutes says it has severed ties with its founder, who has been charged with conspiracy to commit aggravated assault.", "lead_paragraph": "In part because of David Elms, the business of prostitution is moving  from street corners and hotel bars to the Internet. Mr. Elms founded The Erotic Review, a Web site where patrons of prostitutes go to rate their experiences. It\u2019s a bit like Amazon ratings for prostitutes, except of course that paying for books isn\u2019t illegal in most jurisdictions.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Prostitution Site Cuts Ties With Founder After Charges", "kicker": "Bits", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [], "pub_date": "2009-03-05T01:05:51+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Technology", "byline": {"original": "By Matt Richtel", "person": [{"firstname": "Matt", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Richtel", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/d8940fd3-3a8c-5295-be2a-acd3c3aab957", "word_count": 649, "uri": "nyt://article/d8940fd3-3a8c-5295-be2a-acd3c3aab957"}, {"abstract": "David Pogue looks at Amazon\u2019s new Kindle e-book application for the iPhone and iPod Touch.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2009/03/05/technology/personaltech/05pogue-email.html", "snippet": "David Pogue looks at Amazon\u2019s new Kindle e-book application for the iPhone and iPod Touch.", "lead_paragraph": "I don't mean to turn this column into All E-Books, All the Time. {"abstract": "A strike by Petrobras workers cut output at refineries in Brazil and also temporarily halted crude production of 60,000 barrels a day and 1.4 million cubic meters of natural gas, union officials said.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2009/03/24/business/24fobriefs-PETROBRASSTR_BRF.html", "snippet": "A strike by Petrobras workers cut output at refineries in Brazil and also temporarily halted crude production of 60,000 barrels a day and 1.4 million cubic meters of natural gas, union officials said.", "lead_paragraph": "A strike by Petrobras workers cut output at refineries in Brazil and also temporarily halted crude production of 60,000 barrels a day and 1.4 million cubic meters of natural gas, union officials said. The walkout over profit-sharing and safety issues may force the company to cut output from about 40 percent of the Campos Basin, Brazil\u2019s main producing region, as well as fields in Brazil\u2019s northeast and Amazon regions, said Marluzio Ferreira, spokesman for the national oil workers federation. Work was also disrupted at 11 refineries, he said. The union says Petrobras has refused requests to improve safety measures, and that 165 employees have been killed since 2002. The union also says the company has sought to cut revenue and profit sharing. Petrobras, which is adding workers, is aiming to reduce costs as oil prices fall and it embarks on a $174.4 billion five-year investment plan. Petrobras said in a statement on its Web site that all its units were operating normally during the strike. ", "print_section": "B", "print_page": "4", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Brazil: Petrobras Strike Impact", "kicker": "World Business Briefing | The Americas", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "Brazil: Petrobras Strike Impact", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Strikes", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Petrobras", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "glocations", "value": "Brazil", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2009-03-24T05:38:01+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Bloomberg News", "person": [{"firstname": "Bloomberg", "middlename": null, "lastname": "News", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "Brief", "_id": "nyt://article/72107b90-8868-597b-8bde-14af4bcfb857", "word_count": 166, "uri": "nyt://article/72107b90-8868-597b-8bde-14af4bcfb857"}

{"abstract": "Amazon will close shipping centers in Indiana, Nevada and Pennsylvania, citing an effort to streamline operations.", "web_url": "https://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/03/26/amazon-to-close-three-distribution-centers/", "snippet": "Amazon will close shipping centers in Indiana, Nevada and Pennsylvania, citing an effort to streamline operations.", "lead_paragraph": "Apparently, today\u2019s a good day for bad news, with Google laying off 200 employees, our own cutbacks here at The Times, and now, Amazon.com weighing in with some cost-cutting of its own. {"abstract": "The free Adobe Reader software has a Read Aloud feature that can audibly recite the contents of many PDF files.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2009/04/09/technology/personaltech/09askk-003.html", "snippet": "The free Adobe Reader software has a Read Aloud feature that can audibly recite the contents of many PDF files.", "lead_paragraph": " You don\u2019t need an Amazon Kindle 2 to have a mechanical box read documents out loud. Although its main function is to display PDF files, the free Adobe Reader software (www.adobe.com/products/reader) has a Read Aloud feature that can audibly recite the contents of many PDF files. To hear it for yourself, open a PDF file, go to the View menu and activate the feature from the Read Out Loud submenu. While copy-protected e-books may not be compatible with Read Out Loud, it is fine for works in the public domain, like books in PDF files from Project Gutenberg (gutenberg.us), academic papers and other PDF files.", "print_section": "B", "print_page": "2", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Tip of the Week: Let Your Documents Do the Talking", "kicker": null, "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Computers and the Internet", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Electronic Books and Readers", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "ADOBE SYSTEMS INC", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2009-04-08T20:48:03+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Technology", "subsection_name": "Personal Tech", "byline": {"original": "By J.D. {"abstract": "At a recent reading in Manhattan by David Sedaris, a reader presented his electronic-book device for the author to sign.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2009/06/15/business/media/15kindle.html", "snippet": "At a recent reading in Manhattan by David Sedaris, a reader presented his electronic-book device for the author to sign.", "lead_paragraph": "At book events, bibliophiles typically wait in line to present books to pen-wielding authors, but as readers increasingly turn to electronic-book devices like the Kindle, it raises the question of whether book-signings may one day go the way of the inkwell.", "print_section": "B", "print_page": "5", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Kindle Joins a Literary Ritual: Authors Can Autograph It", "kicker": null, "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "Kindle Joins a Literary Ritual: Authors Can Autograph It", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Amazon Kindle", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Writing and Writers", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Electronic Books and Readers", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Books and Literature", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2009-06-15T02:35:57+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "Media", "byline": {"original": "By Andrew Adam Newman", "person": [{"firstname": "Andrew", "middlename": "Adam", "lastname": "Newman", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/9a7fe018-f829-5b83-85d9-39c3a472cb10", "word_count": 384, "uri": "nyt://article/9a7fe018-f829-5b83-85d9-39c3a472cb10"}

{"abstract": "Amazon has cut the price of its popular electronic reading device by $60, to $299.", "web_url": "https://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/07/08/amazon-cuts-prices-on-the-kindle-2/", "snippet": "Amazon has cut the price of its popular electronic reading device by $60, to $299.", "lead_paragraph": "It\u2019s not the holiday sales season yet, but Amazon has already cut the price of its latest Kindle model to $299, from $359 when it was introduced in February.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Amazon Trims Price of the Kindle 2", "kicker": "Bits", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [], "pub_date": "2009-07-09T00:00:07+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Technology", "byline": {"original": "By Brad Stone", "person": [{"firstname": "Brad", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Stone", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/7ec18b25-1e9c-547a-bfba-c8d6b0271634", "word_count": 237, "uri": "nyt://article/7ec18b25-1e9c-547a-bfba-c8d6b0271634"}

{"abstract": "Amazon.com deleted purchased e-book copies of George Orwell\u2019s \u201c1984\u201d and \u201cAnimal Farm\u201d from customers\u2019 Kindle devices after the company determined the editions were unauthorized.", "web_url": "https://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/07/17/amazoncom-plays-big-brother-with-a-famous-e-book/", "snippet": "Amazon.com deleted purchased e-book copies of George Orwell\u2019s \u201c1984\u201d and \u201cAnimal Farm\u201d from customers\u2019 Kindle devices after the company determined the editions were unauthorized.", "lead_paragraph": "EDITOR\u2019S NOTE | 8:41 p.m.  The Times published an article explaining that the Orwell books were unauthorized editions that Amazon removed from its Kindle store. {"abstract": "An Amazon spokesman said that \u201c1984\u201d and \u201cAnimal Farm\u201d were added to the Kindle store by a company that did not have rights to them, using a self-service function.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2009/07/18/technology/companies/18amazon.html", "snippet": "An Amazon spokesman said that \u201c1984\u201d and \u201cAnimal Farm\u201d were added to the Kindle store by a company that did not have rights to them, using a self-service function.", "lead_paragraph": "In George Orwell\u2019s \u201c1984,\u201d government censors erase all traces of news articles embarrassing to Big Brother by sending them down an incineration chute called the \u201cmemory hole.\u201d", "print_section": "B", "print_page": "1", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [{"rank": 0, "subtype": "xlarge", "caption": null, "credit": null, "type": "image", "url": "images/2009/07/18/business/18amazonA_xl.jpg", "height": 330, "width": 600, "subType": "xlarge", "crop_name": "articleLarge", "legacy": {"xlarge": "images/2009/07/18/business/18amazonA_xl.jpg", "xlargewidth": 600, "xlargeheight": 330}}, {"rank": 0, "subtype": "thumbnail", "caption": null, "credit": null, "type": "image", "url": "images/2009/07/18/business/18amazonA_75.jpg", "height": 75, "width": 75, "subType": "thumbnail", "crop_name": "thumbStandard", "legacy": {"thumbnail": "images/2009/07/18/business/18amazonA_75.jpg", "thumbnailwidth": 75, "thumbnailheight": 75}}], "headline": {"main": "Amazon Erases Orwell Books From Kindle", "kicker": null, "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "Amazon Erases Two Classics From Kindle. {"abstract": "Some Kindle fans want Amazon to give up its use of digital rights management, which allows the company to maintain strict control of its e-books.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2009/07/27/technology/companies/27amazon.html", "snippet": "Some Kindle fans want Amazon to give up its use of digital rights management, which allows the company to maintain strict control of its e-books.", "lead_paragraph": "SAN FRANCISCO \u0097 Last week, Jeffrey P. {"abstract": "The Target Corporation plans to run its own Web site starting in 2011, ending a 10-year deal under with Amazon.com.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2009/08/08/business/08bizbriefs-target.html", "snippet": "The Target Corporation plans to run its own Web site starting in 2011, ending a 10-year deal under with Amazon.com.", "lead_paragraph": "The Target Corporation plans to run its own Web site starting in 2011, ending a 10-year deal under which Amazon.com fills the site\u2019s orders and provides customer support. Target, the second-largest discount retailer in the United States, after Wal-Mart, will take over building and managing Target.com before the 2011 holiday season, the company said in a statement on Friday. Amazon, the world\u2019s largest online retailer, agreed in 2001 to provide customer care, technology and order fulfillment for Target.com to help the discount retailer lower costs and improve customer service. \u201cWe\u2019ve had a very positive, productive relationship with Amazon,\u201d Kelly Basgen, a Target spokeswoman, said. However, she added, \u201cWe just thought it was in our best interest to grow and manage our own platform.\u201d Target said it would work with Amazon until the contract expired. ", "print_section": "B", "print_page": "2", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Target to End Deal With Amazon to Run Its Web Site", "kicker": "Business Briefing | Company News", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "Target to End Deal With Amazon to Run Its Web Site", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Shopping and Retail", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "AMAZON.COM INC", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Target Corp", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Computers and the Internet", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2009-08-08T01:25:44+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Bloomberg News", "person": [{"firstname": "Bloomberg", "middlename": null, "lastname": "News", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "Brief", "_id": "nyt://article/5943e6bf-a397-5c69-b522-3c672f5e39f4", "word_count": 137, "uri": "nyt://article/5943e6bf-a397-5c69-b522-3c672f5e39f4"}

{"abstract": "A coalition that includes Amazon, Microsoft and Yahoo explains its arguments against the settlement.", "web_url": "https://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/08/26/coalition-lays-out-arguments-against-google-books-settlement/", "snippet": "A coalition that includes Amazon, Microsoft and Yahoo explains its arguments against the settlement.", "lead_paragraph": "Last week, we reported that Amazon, Microsoft and Yahoo were joining a new coalition of individuals, companies, libraries and nonprofit groups that are opposing the far-reaching settlement of a lawsuit between Google and groups representing publishers and authors. {"abstract": "Chevron said it had video recordings of meetings in Ecuador that appear to reveal a bribery scheme tied to a $27 billion lawsuit the company faces over environmental damage at oil fields in the Amazon forest, The New York Times\u2019s Simon Romero and Clifford Krauss reported.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2009/09/01/chevron-offers-evidence-of-bribery-in-ecuador-suit/", "snippet": "Chevron said it had video recordings of meetings in Ecuador that appear to reveal a bribery scheme tied to a $27 billion lawsuit the company faces over environmental damage at oil fields in the Amazon forest, The New York Times\u2019s Simon Romero and ...", "lead_paragraph": "The oil giant Chevron said Monday that it had obtained video recordings of meetings in Ecuador this year that appear to reveal a bribery scheme connected to a $27 billion lawsuit the company faces over environmental damage at oil fields it operated in remote areas of the Amazon forest in Ecuador, The New York Times\u2019s Simon Romero and Clifford Krauss reported. {"abstract": "The Zappos story is inspiring, thought-provoking and impressive. I was hoping for a little math.", "web_url": "https://boss.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/09/24/of-shoes-and-happiness/", "snippet": "The Zappos story is inspiring, thought-provoking and impressive. I was hoping for a little math.", "lead_paragraph": "The first big speech at the Inc. 500 Conference, where I\u2019m blogging today, was by Tony Hsieh, the chief executive of Zappos. For those (few) of you who have never heard of Zappos, it is the online store based in Las Vegas that sells mostly shoes, has just hit a billion dollars in sales and was just bought by Amazon for fairly close to a billion dollars. A very interesting story and a very impressive track record.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Of Shoes and Happiness", "kicker": "You're the Boss", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [], "pub_date": "2009-09-24T19:15:56+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "Entrepreneurship", "byline": {"original": "By Jay Goltz", "person": [{"firstname": "Jay", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Goltz", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "", "_id": "nyt://article/a6a6cdc4-8bb3-5528-bce3-f575c9dab4ae", "word_count": 385, "uri": "nyt://article/a6a6cdc4-8bb3-5528-bce3-f575c9dab4ae"}

{"abstract": "If Amazon allowed third-party developers to make applications for the Kindle, it could turn a device with a single purpose into something much more flexible.", "web_url": "https://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/09/25/will-amazon-open-the-kindle-to-developers/", "snippet": "If Amazon allowed third-party developers to make applications for the Kindle, it could turn a device with a single purpose into something much more flexible.", "lead_paragraph": "We\u2019re heading into the holiday buying season, which means the introduction of new gadgets and the media\u2019s annual anointment of the season\u2019s hottest tech toy. {"abstract": "Target and Wal-Mart, trying to beat their online competitor Amazon, continue to lower book prices, albeit as slightly as possible. When one charges $8.99, the other shifts to $8.98. {"abstract": "A research group asked people to evaluate two services: Amazon\u2019s Video on Demand and Netflix\u2019s Watch Instantly.", "web_url": "https://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/11/04/amazon-video-vs-netflix-which-will-prevail/", "snippet": "A research group asked people to evaluate two services: Amazon\u2019s Video on Demand and Netflix\u2019s Watch Instantly.", "lead_paragraph": "Which business model for watching movies online will be the winner? {"abstract": "Some publishers are delaying the release of electronic versions of best-selling books to drive hardcover sales. But by doing so, they risk alienating their best customers.", "web_url": "https://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/12/15/wary-book-publishers-are-fighting-the-future/", "snippet": "Some publishers are delaying the release of electronic versions of best-selling books to drive hardcover sales. But by doing so, they risk alienating their best customers.", "lead_paragraph": "Last week, a host of book publishers, led by Simon & Schuster, said they will delay publication of e-reader versions of many books because they were afraid the electronic copies were cannibalizing sales of more expensive hardcover editions.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Wary Book Publishers Are Fighting the Future", "kicker": "Bits", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Amazon Kindle", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Book Trade", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Books and Literature", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Electronic Books and Readers", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2009-12-15T18:47:27+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Technology", "byline": {"original": "By Nick Bilton", "person": [{"firstname": "Nick", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Bilton", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "", "_id": "nyt://article/34f12168-c546-5e39-931a-e3d7c24c2455", "word_count": 727, "uri": "nyt://article/34f12168-c546-5e39-931a-e3d7c24c2455"}, {"abstract": "Bits: Are publishers fighting the future when they delay the release of e-book versions?", "web_url": "https://mediadecoder.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/12/15/bits-are-skittish-publishers-fighting-the-future/", "snippet": "Bits: Are publishers fighting the future when they delay the release of e-book versions?", "lead_paragraph": "Nick Bilton wonders whether some publishers are making a mistake in delaying digital versions of their biggest releases in hopes of selling more hardcovers before the e-book sales kick in. Kindle and other such e-readers tend to be purchased by the most loyal and ravenous book buyers, he argues, who are more likely to pay a premium for digital versions of a book. He says those readers are disappointed if they can\u2019t get a new book as soon as they want it on their new, expensive device. Read more\u2026", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Bits: Are Skittish Publishers Fighting the Future?", "kicker": "Media Decoder", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Amazon Kindle", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Books and Literature", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2009-12-15T19:16:51+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Media", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "Media", "byline": {"original": "By The Editors", "person": [], "organization": "The Editors"}, "type_of_material": "", "_id": "nyt://article/5c51f07f-2130-5cf7-a08d-177b472454d5", "word_count": 89, "uri": "nyt://article/5c51f07f-2130-5cf7-a08d-177b472454d5"}]

{"abstract": "Borders joins the e-book revolution with a new e-reader and e-book site created with a Canadian partner. The bookstore chain is entering a market crowded with other e-reading devices.", "lead_paragraph": "Update | 12/16/09 1:42 p.m. A Borders spokeswoman, Anne Roman, says that despite the company\u2019s investment in Kobo, Borders \u201cdoes not have a part in the technical development of these devices.\u201d In addition, Borders plans to \u201coffer an assortment of devices\u201d but has made no commitment to carry the Kobo e-reader when it is released next year. [{"abstract": "Amazon removed Macmillan books from its site in a dispute over prices of e-books.", "web_url": "https://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/01/29/amazon-pulls-macmillan-books-over-e-book-price-disagreement/", "snippet": "Amazon removed Macmillan books from its site in a dispute over prices of e-books.", "lead_paragraph": "Update | 7:01 p.m. Amazon relents and is selling Macmillan books again.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Amazon Pulls Macmillan Books Over E-Book Price Disagreement", "kicker": "Bits", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "organizations", "value": "AMAZON.COM INC", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2010-01-30T04:19:18+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Technology", "byline": {"original": "By Brad Stone", "person": [{"firstname": "Brad", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Stone", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "", "_id": "nyt://article/8a7eca20-f34b-58ad-a413-4a55f4599e97", "word_count": 386, "uri": "nyt://article/8a7eca20-f34b-58ad-a413-4a55f4599e97"}, {"abstract": "Bits: Amazon has pulled Macmillan titles from its site in a disagreement over e-book pricing.", "web_url": "https://mediadecoder.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/01/29/bits-amazon-pulls-macmillan-books-from-its-site/", "snippet": "Bits: Amazon has pulled Macmillan titles from its site in a disagreement over e-book pricing.", "lead_paragraph": "Amazon has pulled books published by Macmillan from its site in a disagreement between the online retailer and the publisher over the price of e-books. For the moment, Macmillan books are available on Amazon only when bought through third parties. Macmillan, like other publishers, has been wrangling with Amazon over the retailer\u2019s insistence that all e-books for its Kindle device be priced at $9.99. Many publishers want to charge more, or at least have more control over prices for individual books. The dispute hit a new level this week when Apple introduced its new iPad device, which will have an iBooks application through which publishers will have more control over e-book prices. The full story is here. [{"abstract": "While it seems to have surrendered to a publisher\u2019s demands for higher e-book prices, Amazon is still keeping many Macmillan books off of its site.", "web_url": "https://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/02/02/macmillan-books-still-mostly-absent-from-amazoncom/", "snippet": "While it seems to have surrendered to a publisher\u2019s demands for higher e-book prices, Amazon is still keeping many Macmillan books off of its site.", "lead_paragraph": "On Sunday, Amazon.com appeared to wave the white flag of surrender in its war with book publishers over e-book prices. But as it turns out, the battle is still raging.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Macmillan Books Still Mostly Absent From Amazon.com", "kicker": "Bits", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "organizations", "value": "AMAZON.COM INC", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Macmillan Publishers", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2010-02-02T19:19:38+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Technology", "byline": {"original": "By Motoko Rich and Brad Stone", "person": [{"firstname": "Motoko", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Rich", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}, {"firstname": "Brad", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Stone", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 2}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "", "_id": "nyt://article/a59c43ec-9feb-50b6-abc3-821632e41707", "word_count": 194, "uri": "nyt://article/a59c43ec-9feb-50b6-abc3-821632e41707"}, {"abstract": "Bits: Amazon and Macmillan talks continue, with most Macmillan titles still absent from Amazon\u2019s Web site.", "web_url": "https://mediadecoder.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/02/02/bits-macmillan-books-still-largely-absent-on-amazon/", "snippet": "Bits: Amazon and Macmillan talks continue, with most Macmillan titles still absent from Amazon\u2019s Web site.", "lead_paragraph": "On Sunday, Amazon appeared to surrender to Macmillan in a dispute over the pricing of e-books. Macmillan, like other publishers, wanted more control over prices for their digital books. At first, Amazon responded by removing Macmillan titles, both digital and paper, from its site, except when bought through third-party vendors. Then, Amazon seemed to back down. But the talks are continuing, and Macmillan titles are still mostly absent from the Amazon site. Read the full story here. {"abstract": "Amazon.com is pushing newspaper, magazine and book publishers to guarantee that Kindle customers will get the lowest prices on electronic content. In return, publishers may get a bigger cut of the revenue.", "lead_paragraph": "On Jan. 27, Steven P. [{"abstract": "Barnes & Noble started a round of e-reader price-cutting by dropping the price of the original Nook.", "web_url": "https://mediadecoder.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/06/21/for-e-readers-a-price-war/", "snippet": "Barnes & Noble started a round of e-reader price-cutting by dropping the price of the original Nook.", "lead_paragraph": "On our sister blog, Bits, Brad Stone reports that on Monday, Barnes & Noble started a round of e-reader price-cutting by dropping the price of the original Nook, with Wi-Fi and 3G wireless connectivity, to $199 from $259. It also introduced a new, Wi-Fi-only Nook at $149. {"abstract": "Apple has sold more than three million iPads since April, but Amazon\u2019s success with the Kindle is cloudier because it doesn\u2019t reveal sales numbers.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2010/08/08/business/08digi.html", "snippet": "Apple has sold more than three million iPads since April, but Amazon\u2019s success with the Kindle is cloudier because it doesn\u2019t reveal sales numbers.", "lead_paragraph": "THE Kindle from Amazon.com is designed to let us do one thing very well: read. To survive, it must excel at this, not only by jostling to stay a nose ahead of other e-readers, but also by maintaining an enormous lead over the Apple iPad and its coming competitors. The multipurpose iPad can do thousands of things very well; used for reading book-length texts, it doesn\u2019t excel, but it\u2019s passable. {"abstract": "Deepak Chopra\u2019s fictionalized biography about the life of the Prophet Muhammad will go on sale early in e-book form, weeks ahead of the print book\u2019s publication date of Sept. 21.", "web_url": "https://mediadecoder.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/09/08/artsbeat-deepak-chopras-muhammad-to-be-released-early-as-e-book/", "snippet": "Deepak Chopra\u2019s fictionalized biography about the life of the Prophet Muhammad will go on sale early in e-book form, weeks ahead of the print book\u2019s publication date of Sept. 21.", "lead_paragraph": "\u201cMuhammad,\u201d Deepak Chopra\u2019s fictionalized biography about the life of the Prophet Muhammad, will go on sale early in e-book form, weeks ahead of the print book\u2019s publication date of Sept. 21. HarperCollins, the book\u2019s publisher, said it had authorized Amazon and other e-book retailers to sell the book beginning Wednesday, trying to meet demand for the book since the national conversation has turned to Islam and the planned community center and mosque near ground zero. Read more at ArtsBeat\u2026", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "ArtsBeat: Deepak Chopra\u2019s \u2018Muhammad\u2019 to Be Released Early as E-Book", "kicker": "Media Decoder", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [], "pub_date": "2010-09-08T19:26:42+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "Media", "byline": {"original": "By Julie Bosman", "person": [{"firstname": "Julie", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Bosman", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "", "_id": "nyt://article/585ed3b1-da80-54f1-a271-68bed1a6aed5", "word_count": 79, "uri": "nyt://article/585ed3b1-da80-54f1-a271-68bed1a6aed5"}

{"abstract": "New technologies are most commonly encountered through co-workers or as part of a corporate system, but retiring doesn\u2019t have to mean falling out of touch.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/03/business/retirementspecial/03Tech.html", "snippet": "New technologies are most commonly encountered through co-workers or as part of a corporate system, but retiring doesn\u2019t have to mean falling out of touch.", "lead_paragraph": "HERE is the problem with typical \u201celder tech\u201d products: there\u2019s not enough \u201ctech\u201d in a phone that uses an oversize keypad but offers limited features, for one example. Advancing age can rob people of their abilities, and products that help mitigate that are good things indeed. But what if the need for that kind of assistance is still decades away? Today\u2019s baby boomers are just now crossing the retirement line, but that does not render them incapacitated. Far from it. It may, however, render them out of touch. {"abstract": "Companies are expected to reassess backup and recovery after the interruption at Amazon Web Services.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2011/04/23/technology/23cloud.html", {"abstract": "Google is said to be in negotiations with the major record labels to expand a cloud music service and also open an MP3 store that would compete with Apple and Amazon.", "web_url": "https://mediadecoder.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/10/13/google-said-to-be-planning-an-mp3-store/", "snippet": "Google is said to be in negotiations with the major record labels to expand a cloud music service and also open an MP3 store that would compete with Apple and Amazon.", "lead_paragraph": "Five months after it introduced a cloud music service with limited capabilities, Google is in negotiations with the major record labels to expand that service and also open an MP3 store that would compete with Apple and Amazon.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Google Said to Be Planning an MP3 Store", "kicker": "Media Decoder", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Cloud Computing", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Music", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "AMAZON.COM INC", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Apple Incorporated", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Google Inc", "rank": 5, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "iTunes", "rank": 6, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2011-10-13T19:03:17+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "Media", "byline": {"original": "By Ben Sisario", "person": [{"firstname": "Ben", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Sisario", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/42a096f9-88ca-51fd-943e-601d1fba43f1", "word_count": 369, "uri": "nyt://article/42a096f9-88ca-51fd-943e-601d1fba43f1"}

small businesses.", "web_url": "https://boss.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/12/12/the-backlash-to-amazons-price-check-promotion-builds/", "snippet": "The online giant says the promotion, which encouraged customers to report local retailers\u2019 prices to Amazon, was not aimed at small businesses.", "lead_paragraph": "For years \u2014 since its inception \u2014 Amazon has been at implicit war with local brick-and-mortar stores. Last week, the implicit seemingly became explicit when Amazon began a promotion that encouraged customers to check out prices at local retailers and use a specially designed \u201cPrice Check\u201d smartphone app to report what they found back to Amazon. Customers who then purchased the same item from Amazon received a 5 percent discount, up to $5. (The deal was available only from Friday night through Saturday, and only for certain kinds of products.)", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Amazon Denies It Has a Small-Business Problem", "kicker": "You're the Boss", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Sales and Excise Taxes", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Shopping and Retail", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Small Business", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "persons", "value": "Snowe, Olympia", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2011-12-12T16:00:20+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "Entrepreneurship", "byline": {"original": "By Robb Mandelbaum", "person": [{"firstname": "Robb", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Mandelbaum", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/2b7e4ebd-7bf8-5da7-a905-8aae102abd0c", "word_count": 764, "uri": "nyt://article/2b7e4ebd-7bf8-5da7-a905-8aae102abd0c"}]

[{"abstract": "The key to Amazon\u2019s success over the years has been its relentlessness. Most retailers hit a cruising speed and stay there. Amazon, for better or worse, keeps accelerating. Amazon\u2019s millions of customers do not mind its aggressive tactics. Yet.", "web_url": "https://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/12/14/for-amazon-lashes-and-backlashes/", "snippet": "The key to Amazon\u2019s success over the years has been its relentlessness. Most retailers hit a cruising speed and stay there. Amazon, for better or worse, keeps accelerating. Amazon\u2019s millions of customers do not mind its aggressive tactics. Yet.", "lead_paragraph": "If Amazon had a secret agenda in 2011 to fuel a backlash against itself, the retailer has scored another triumph. Its refusal to collect sales tax in California despite a new law compelling it to do so prompted some well-publicized criticism not only from politicians but the tech community. Its hiring of ambulances at its Pennsylvania warehouse to wait for workers to keel over in the summer heat conjured up a Dickensian sweatshop. The retailer apparently brought its Kindle Fire tablet to market before it had all the kinks out, disappointing some of its biggest fans.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "For Amazon, Lashes and Backlashes", "kicker": "Bits", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Book Trade and Publishing", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Shopping and Retail", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "persons", "value": "Russo, Richard (1949- )", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "AMAZON.COM INC", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2011-12-14T20:09:13+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Technology", "byline": {"original": "By David Streitfeld", "person": [{"firstname": "David", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Streitfeld", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/007a8dda-8b50-5ea2-aeb1-2aefc4e5dfe9", "word_count": 603, "uri": "nyt://article/007a8dda-8b50-5ea2-aeb1-2aefc4e5dfe9"}, {"abstract": "The tech reporters and editors of The New York Times are always searching for interesting items on the Web. {"abstract": "Amazon.com, under its chief, Jeff Bezos, follows a growth-oriented strategy that sometimes disappoints investors who want near-term profit.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2011/12/17/business/at-amazon-jeff-bezos-talks-long-term-and-means-it.html", "snippet": "Amazon.com, under its chief, Jeff Bezos, follows a growth-oriented strategy that sometimes disappoints investors who want near-term profit.", "lead_paragraph": "In 1997, the year Amazon.com went public, its chief executive, Jeff Bezos, issued a manifesto: \u201cIt\u2019s all about the long term,\u201d he said. He warned shareholders \u201cwe may make decisions and weigh tradeoffs differently than some companies\u201d and urged them to make sure that a long-term approach \u201cis consistent with your investment policy.\u201d Amazon\u2019s management and employees \u201care working to build something important, something that matters to our customers, something that we can tell our grandchildren about,\u201d he added.", "print_section": "B", "print_page": "1", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [{"rank": 0, "subtype": "xlarge", "caption": null, "credit": null, "type": "image", {"abstract": "Several publishers have barred libraries from buying their e-books, saying that allowing unlimited e-reading isn\u2019t a sustainable business model. But one publisher is trying a different approach.", "lead_paragraph": "LAST year, Christmas was the biggest single day for e-book sales by HarperCollins. And indications are that this year\u2019s Christmas Day total will be even higher, given the extremely strong sales of e-readers like the Kindle and the Nook. {"abstract": "Some fear that a price-fixing lawsuit might give Amazon a pass to offer discounts that could put its competitors out of business.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2012/04/18/business/economy/competition-needs-protection.html", "snippet": "Some fear that a price-fixing lawsuit might give Amazon a pass to offer discounts that could put its competitors out of business.", "lead_paragraph": "To believe publishers and authors, the government just handed Amazon a monopoly over the book market: The price-fixing suit against Apple and the nation\u2019s top publishers filed by the Justice Department last week will free Amazon to offer ruinous discounts in the booming new market of electronic books, drive brick-and-mortar bookstores out of existence and kill off publishers\u2019 lucrative business of ink on paper. [{"abstract": "In Georgia, a university\u2019s journalism department injects life and resources into local coverage, and a chronicler of police misconduct in Harlem says he has been punished for his work.", "web_url": "https://mediadecoder.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/09/10/the-breakfast-meeting-journalisms-big-tent-and-google-vs-amazon-on-search/", "snippet": "In Georgia, a university\u2019s journalism department injects life and resources into local coverage, and a chronicler of police misconduct in Harlem says he has been punished for his work.", "lead_paragraph": "An experiment in journalism education at Mercer University in Macon, Ga., will also inject life and resources into the professional journalism in the city, Christine Haughney writes. Backed by a $4.6 million grant from the John S. and James L. Knight Foundation, Mercer\u2019s Center for Collaborative Journalism will be home to reporters and editors of the city\u2019s 186-year-old paper, The Telegraph, and the local public radio station. Students will do reporting legwork, with guidance from professors and working journalists, in what the university\u2019s president compares to the way medical schools use hospitals to train their students.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "The Breakfast Meeting: Journalism\u2019s Big Tent, and Google vs. Amazon on Search", "kicker": "Media Decoder", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [], "pub_date": "2012-09-10T13:40:40+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "Media", "byline": {"original": "By NOAM COHEN", "person": [{"firstname": "Noam", "middlename": null, "lastname": "COHEN", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/525e9572-03db-5300-908d-056957883b10", "word_count": 525, "uri": "nyt://article/525e9572-03db-5300-908d-056957883b10"}, {"abstract": "The deals come just days after a judge approved a settlement by HarperCollins and two other publishers that prohibit publishers from restricting a retailer\u2019s ability to set prices for e-books.", "web_url": "https://mediadecoder.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/09/10/harpercollins-reaches-new-agreements-with-amazon-and-others-on-e-book-prices/", "snippet": "The deals come just days after a judge approved a settlement by HarperCollins and two other publishers that prohibit publishers from restricting a retailer\u2019s ability to set prices for e-books.", "lead_paragraph": "HarperCollins has struck new agreements with Amazon and other retailers that allow its e-books to be sold at a discount, the publisher said on Monday. {"abstract": "The European Commission said it would end an e-book pricing investigation of Apple and four e-book publishers if they temporarily allowed online retailers to sell at a discount.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2012/09/20/business/global/agreement-could-end-europes-e-book-price-fixing-inquiry.html", "snippet": "The European Commission said it would end an e-book pricing investigation of Apple and four e-book publishers if they temporarily allowed online retailers to sell at a discount.", "lead_paragraph": "BERLIN \u2014 The European Commission said Wednesday that it was prepared to drop its investigation into the fixing of e-book prices by Apple and four European publishers after the companies agreed to let online retailers like Amazon sell e-books at a discount for two years.", "print_section": "B", "print_page": "2", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Tentative Deal on E-Book Prices Is Reached in Europe", "kicker": null, "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "Tentative Deal on E-Book Prices Is Reached in Europe", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "E-Books and Readers", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "European Commission", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "E-Commerce", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Apple Inc", "rank": 5, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Book Trade and Publishing", "rank": 6, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2012-09-19T19:56:27+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "Global Business", "byline": {"original": "By Kevin J. {"abstract": "Also, overseas publishers take on Google News, the continuing dispute over online music royalties, and BBC executives who missed opportunities to learn more about allegations of sexual abuse against Jimmy Savile.", "web_url": "https://mediadecoder.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/11/05/the-breakfast-meeting-restraint-on-election-day-and-revenge-against-amazon/", "snippet": "Also, overseas publishers take on Google News, the continuing dispute over online music royalties, and BBC executives who missed opportunities to learn more about allegations of sexual abuse against Jimmy Savile.", "lead_paragraph": "Executives at the TV networks and other news gathering operations said they were committed to holding off proclaiming a winner in the presidential election on Tuesday until they were confident of a winner, Brian Stelter reported. {"abstract": "The year is ending on a strong note for the movie industry, with the number of tickets sold increasing by more than 5 percent; Bill O\u2019Reilly is finding great success in telling the story of the assassinations of Lincoln and Kennedy; Amazon is purging users\u2019 book reviews that seem to betray a conflict; and more.", "web_url": "https://mediadecoder.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/12/24/the-breakfast-meeting-hollywoods-2012-comeback-and-reviewing-amazons-reviews/", "snippet": "The year is ending on a strong note for the movie industry, with the number of tickets sold increasing by more than 5 percent; Bill O\u2019Reilly is finding great success in telling the story of the assassinations of Lincoln and Kennedy; Amazon is purg...", "lead_paragraph": "Movie attendance was up 5.6 percent, despite a weak summer, punctuated by mass killings at a screening in Aurora, Colo., of the latest Batman feature, Brooks Barnes writes. Ticket revenue at North American theaters is projected to jump by 6 percent, to $10.8 billion, according to an analysis by Hollywood.com. In 2012, industry executives say, the increase from foreign sales was even more critical, salvaging the prospects of movies that were mild disappointments in the United States like \u201cIce Age: Continental Drift,\u201d from 20th Century Fox, which made $68 million in China alone.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "The Breakfast Meeting: Hollywood\u2019s 2012 Comeback, and Reviewing Amazon\u2019s Reviews", "kicker": "Media Decoder", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "persons", "value": "Dugard, Martin", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "persons", "value": "O'Reilly, Bill", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "AMAZON.COM INC", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Lions Gate Entertainment Corporation", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Seventeen (Magazine)", "rank": 5, "major": "N"}, {"name": "glocations", "value": "China", "rank": 6, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2012-12-24T15:00:26+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "Media", "byline": {"original": "By Noam Cohen", "person": [{"firstname": "Noam", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Cohen", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/30915e98-50b3-5aed-906b-1519b62f8129", "word_count": 624, "uri": "nyt://article/30915e98-50b3-5aed-906b-1519b62f8129"}

{"abstract": "Amazon.com is quietly building a library of exclusive online content to rival Netflix, the champion of streaming media; cat videos are used to sell things rather than simply distract; and a Japanese television show captures the angst of a major lithium-ion battery manufacturer.", "web_url": "https://mediadecoder.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/02/12/the-breakfast-meeting-amazon-challenges-netflix-and-an-advertiser-turns-to-cat-videos/", "snippet": "Amazon.com is quietly building a library of exclusive online content to rival Netflix, the champion of streaming media; cat videos are used to sell things rather than simply distract; and a Japanese television show captures the angst of a major li...", "lead_paragraph": "Amazon.com is slowly building a library of streaming television shows and movies to rival that of Netflix, much to the satisfaction of media companies like Time Warner and CBS, Brian Stelter writes. Amazon will not unveil its own original shows until fall at the earliest, but it has spent hundreds of millions of dollars to win exclusive Web rights on shows for its Amazon Prime streaming service, like \u201cDownton Abbey\u201d from PBS and \u201cFalling Skies\u201d from TNT. Amazon is a long way from matching Netflix in terms of TV and movie selection, but parts of the media business already see the company as Pepsi to Netflix\u2019s Coke. Other companies, including Google, Sony, Intel and a new venture by Redbox and Verizon, are scrambling for a Snapple or Red Bull.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "The Breakfast Meeting: Amazon Challenges Netflix, and an Advertiser Turns to Cat Videos", "kicker": "Media Decoder", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [], "pub_date": "2013-02-12T13:26:52+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "Media", "byline": {"original": "By Daniel E. {"abstract": "Consolidation in the sector is long overdue, as the encroaching power of the likes of Amazon and Target has been evident for years, the author writes.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2013/02/19/for-office-supply-stores-an-obvious-merger/", "snippet": "Consolidation in the sector is long overdue, as the encroaching power of the likes of Amazon and Target has been evident for years, the author writes.", "lead_paragraph": "Office Depot and OfficeMax are lucky to have each other. Uniting the two purveyors of pens, paper clips and printer toner is about as obvious as it gets in mergers and acquisitions. The potential synergies could be worth more than the market value of the two companies combined. As the Internet ravishes retailing, at least this corner can cling to life by merger.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "For Office Supply Stores, an Obvious Merger", "kicker": "DealBook", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Office Supplies and Equipment", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Shopping and Retail", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Office Depot Inc.", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "OfficeMax Inc", "rank": 5, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2013-02-19T19:43:02+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Christopher Swann", "person": [{"firstname": "Christopher", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Swann", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/b6d30b64-7b1b-5bad-9fff-3735ff209bf9", "word_count": 370, "uri": "nyt://article/b6d30b64-7b1b-5bad-9fff-3735ff209bf9"}

{"abstract": "Apple and Amazon are trying to make it possible for Web consumers to swap content on a grand scale, Time Warner\u2019s spinoff of Time Inc. is the latest evidence of a strategy of divestment, and Facebook\u2019s redesign strategy is already popular with advertisers.", "web_url": "https://mediadecoder.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/03/08/the-breakfast-meeting-new-ways-to-swap-e-content-and-time-warners-spinoff-trend/", "snippet": "Apple and Amazon are trying to make it possible for Web consumers to swap content on a grand scale, Time Warner\u2019s spinoff of Time Inc. is the latest evidence of a strategy of divestment, and Facebook\u2019s redesign strategy is already popular with adv...", "lead_paragraph": "Apple and Amazon, the two largest purveyors of digital media, are working to create a kind of online swap meet where consumers can exchange music, movies or e-books, David Streitfeld writes. Buyers basically rent iTunes songs or Kindle books under the current system, with no way to transfer the content. The exchanges would allow users to trade content without reproducing it \u2014 when a song is traded, it disappears from its original owner\u2019s library. Publishers and music companies are against this kind of trading, as they believe it could devalue their products, while libraries, which have not been able to dispense e-books very openly, are generally in favor.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "The Breakfast Meeting: New Ways to Swap E-Content and Time Warner\u2019s Spinoff Trend", "kicker": "Media Decoder", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "ADVERTISING AND MARKETING", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "E-Books and Readers", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Media", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "persons", "value": "Zuckerberg, Mark E", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Facebook Inc", "rank": 5, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Time Inc", "rank": 6, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Time Warner Inc", "rank": 7, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Unilever NV", "rank": 8, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2013-03-08T13:42:28+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "Media", "byline": {"original": "By Daniel E. {"abstract": "I didn\u2019t want to go into debt learning business principles so that I could one day hope to build Fashioning Change; I wanted to build Fashioning Change.", "web_url": "https://boss.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/05/08/how-we-keep-our-mentors-and-investors-on-board/", "snippet": "I didn\u2019t want to go into debt learning business principles so that I could one day hope to build Fashioning Change; I wanted to build Fashioning Change.", "lead_paragraph": "When I came up with the idea for Fashioning Change, I had no idea what it meant to create a technology start-up. {"abstract": "In testimony prepared for delivery in court next week, Steven Donziger is as defiant as ever, even as he acknowledges mistakes.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2013/11/14/business/energy-environment/lawyer-concedes-mistakes-in-chevron-case.html", "snippet": "In testimony prepared for delivery in court next week, Steven Donziger is as defiant as ever, even as he acknowledges mistakes.", "lead_paragraph": "For the last month, Chevron has presented a parade of witnesses against Steven R. Donziger, the freelance lawyer who has been suing the company for 20 years over pollution of the Ecuadorean Amazon jungle. {"abstract": "A lawyer for the oil company questioned Steven R. {"abstract": "Transportation and terrain were surmountable production challenges for the co-founder of the beverage company Runa.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2014/03/11/business/international/fruitful-but-tough-adventures-in-the-amazon.html", "snippet": "Transportation and terrain were surmountable production challenges for the co-founder of the beverage company Runa.", "lead_paragraph": "WHEN I was younger we went on a lot of vacations, so traveling isn\u2019t new to me. My business partner Tyler Gage and I went to Ecuador and other parts of South America when we were in college, and after taking an entrepreneurship class we started our beverage company, Runa. We work with more than 2,000 guayusa growers who are all members of the Amazonian Kichwa indigenous group. {"abstract": "With the Fire TV, Amazon is leveraging its position as a retailer to expand into new fields, something it has become very good at.", "web_url": "https://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/04/03/daily-report-amazons-fire-tv-is-a-bid-to-take-over-the-living-room/", "snippet": "With the Fire TV, Amazon is leveraging its position as a retailer to expand into new fields, something it has become very good at.", "lead_paragraph": "The streaming media device that Amazon began selling on Wednesday, Fire TV, is part of the company\u2019s multibillion-dollar effort to move from selling goods produced by others, which is traditionally a low-margin business, to presiding over the entire process of creation and consumption, David Streitfeld reports.
