{"abstract": "Snapchat\u2019s founders are hoping to transform the company\u2019s product into something more sophisticated and sleek, a primary hub for mobile messaging.", "web_url": "https://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/05/01/snapchat-goes-after-mobile-messaging-with-a-new-design/", "snippet": "Snapchat\u2019s founders are hoping to transform the company\u2019s product into something more sophisticated and sleek, a primary hub for mobile messaging.", "lead_paragraph": "The last few years have been a roller coaster for Snapchat, the ephemeral photo-messaging service. Since it started in 2011, the company has made headlines for turning down billions from potential buyers and luring heavyweight talent from Facebook, Google and Amazon, facing criticism over gaping [{"abstract": "Amazon used to take margin from its suppliers so it could sell things more cheaply. Now, it needs the margin for itself.", "web_url": "https://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/05/30/why-is-amazon-squeezing-hachette-maybe-it-really-needs-the-money/", "snippet": "Amazon used to take margin from its suppliers so it could sell things more cheaply. Now, it needs the margin for itself.", "lead_paragraph": "Over the course of nearly two decades, Amazon has hewed to a consistent philosophy: It\u2019s all about the customer. The retailer is so devoted to its customers that it takes the profits that would normally go to shareholders and gives them to shoppers in the form of faster delivery and lower prices. It was a brilliant strategy that has propelled the company to the top ranks of American businesses.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [{"rank": 0, "subtype": "xlarge", "caption": null, "credit": null, "type": "image", "url": "images/2014/05/30/business/30bits-amazon1alt/30bits-amazon1alt-articleLarge.jpg", "height": 400, "width": 600, "subType": "xlarge", "crop_name": "articleLarge", "legacy": {"xlarge": "images/2014/05/30/business/30bits-amazon1alt/30bits-amazon1alt-articleLarge.jpg", "xlargewidth": 600, "xlargeheight": 400}}, {"rank": 0, "subtype": "jumbo", "caption": null, "credit": null, "type": "image", "url": "images/2014/05/30/business/30bits-amazon1alt/30bits-amazon1alt-jumbo.jpg", "height": 683, "width": 1024, "subType": "jumbo", "crop_name": "jumbo", "legacy": {}}, {"rank": 0, "subtype": "superJumbo", "caption": null, "credit": null, "type": "image", "url": "images/2014/05/30/business/30bits-amazon1alt/30bits-amazon1alt-superJumbo.jpg", "height": 1366, "width": 2048, "subType": "superJumbo", "crop_name": "superJumbo", "legacy": {}}, {"rank": 0, "subtype": "thumbnail", "caption": null, "credit": null, "type": "image", "url": "images/2014/05/30/business/30bits-amazon1alt/30bits-amazon1alt-thumbStandard.jpg", "height": 75, "width": 75, "subType": "thumbnail", "crop_name": "thumbStandard", "legacy": {"thumbnail": "images/2014/05/30/business/30bits-amazon1alt/30bits-amazon1alt-thumbStandard.jpg", "thumbnailwidth": 75, "thumbnailheight": 75}}, {"rank": 0, "subtype": "thumbLarge", "caption": null, "credit": null, "type": "image", "url": "images/2014/05/30/business/30bits-amazon1alt/30bits-amazon1alt-thumbLarge.jpg", "height": 150, "width": 150, "subType": "thumbLarge", "crop_name": "thumbLarge", "legacy": {}}], "headline": {"main": "Why Is Amazon Squeezing Hachette? "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2014/08/26/morning-agenda-amazon-scoops-up-twitch/", "snippet": "Amazon has reached a $1.1 billion deal to buy Twitch. | Burger King aims for a fast-food empire. | Bitcoin A.T.M.s are cropping up across the globe. | A summer reading list for your inner financial geek.", "lead_paragraph": "Think video games are just things people play? Think again. On Monday, Amazon announced that it had reached a $1.1 billion deal to buy Twitch, the most popular website for watching people play video games, Nick Wingfield writes in The New York Times. \u201cThe deal for Twitch is the latest sign of how forms of behavior once seemingly on the fringe can, in the hands of tech entrepreneurs, turn into huge online communities in no time,\u201d he writes. Twitch, which specializes in live videos of people playing games, has 55 million unique viewers a month globally.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Morning Agenda: Amazon Scoops Up Twitch", "kicker": "DealBook", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [], "pub_date": "2014-08-26T11:35:26+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Sydney Ember", "person": [{"firstname": "Sydney", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Ember", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/2090687b-e222-5baa-896e-06d909933989", "word_count": 1920, "uri": "nyt://article/2090687b-e222-5baa-896e-06d909933989"}]

{"abstract": "Workers at an Amazon warehouse in Las Vegas, challenging a 1947 law, say the end-of-day process \u2014 aimed at preventing theft \u2014 can take as long as 25 minutes.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2014/10/09/business/supreme-court-weighs-employee-pay-for-amazons-after-work-security-screening.html", "snippet": "Workers at an Amazon warehouse in Las Vegas, challenging a 1947 law, say the end-of-day process \u2014 aimed at preventing theft \u2014 can take as long as 25 minutes.", "lead_paragraph": "WASHINGTON \u2014 The Supreme Court on Wednesday heard arguments over whether workers at an Amazon warehouse in Las Vegas must be paid for the time they spend waiting to go through a security screening at the end of the day. [{"abstract": "A conga line of truth-tellers and liars. Can you tell who\u2019s lying and who\u2019s telling the truth?", "web_url": "https://wordplay.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/11/10/truth-2/", "snippet": "A conga line of truth-tellers and liars. Can you tell who\u2019s lying and who\u2019s telling the truth?", "lead_paragraph": "Our puzzle this week was suggested by Marco Moriconi, a regular Numberplay contributor and professor of physics at the Universidade Federal Fluminense, in Niteroi, Rio de Janeiro. (He also writes a monthly math column for the Brazilian national science magazine, Ci\u00eancia Hoje (Science Today), called Qual o Problema, or \u201cWhat\u2019s the Problem?\u201d). Dr. Moriconi found this week\u2019s puzzle in a blog by its creator, Roy Cook, a professor of philosophy at the University of Minnesota who tells how he momentarily stumped the famous paradox master Raymond Smullyan with the challenge. (Check out Dr. Cook\u2019s recently-published Paradoxes and Dr. Smullyan\u2019s Beginner\u2019s Guide to Mathematical Logic, selected by Amazon as a favorite book of 2014.)", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Truth-Tellers and Liars", "kicker": "Wordplay", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Mathematics", "rank": 7, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Puzzles", "rank": 8, "major": "N"}, {"name": "persons", "value": "Gosper, Bill", "rank": 9, "major": "N"}, {"name": "glocations", "value": "Rio de Janeiro (Brazil)", "rank": 10, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2014-11-10T17:00:59+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Crosswords & Games", "byline": {"original": "By Gary Antonick", "person": [{"firstname": "Gary", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Antonick", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/61a0084e-a050-5850-84ea-1951761262b7", "word_count": 1370, "uri": "nyt://article/61a0084e-a050-5850-84ea-1951761262b7"}, {"abstract": "Plus, tracking an Amazon package by text.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2014/11/07/technology/personaltech/how-to-erase-personal-information-from-an-ipad.html", "snippet": "Plus, tracking an Amazon package by text.", "lead_paragraph": "Q. {"abstract": "Amazon\u2019s \u201call you can eat\u201d reading service, Kindle Unlimited, is driving down prices even as it boosts sales. For self-published authors, that\u2019s a cause for concern.", "web_url": "https://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2015/01/04/for-indie-writers-its-publish-or-perish/", "snippet": "Amazon\u2019s \u201call you can eat\u201d reading service, Kindle Unlimited, is driving down prices even as it boosts sales. For self-published authors, that\u2019s a cause for concern.", "lead_paragraph": "One big argument for \u201call you can eat\u201d music, video and book services is that they encourage people to sample new artists and ultimately develop a deeper relationship with a few of them. You listen to songs you have never heard before because there is no additional cost, and then maybe you go to the concert and, perhaps, buy a T-shirt. Artists are rewarded at the end of the process, not in the beginning the way they used to be.", "print_section": "B", "print_page": "5", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [{"rank": 0, {"abstract": "The move is a departure for Yelp, whose main business has been selling advertising bought by local businesses with those reviews.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2015/02/11/business/yelp-pays-134-million-for-food-ordering-service.html", "snippet": "The move is a departure for Yelp, whose main business has been selling advertising bought by local businesses with those reviews.", "lead_paragraph": "The online review service Yelp said on Tuesday that it had acquired Eat24, an online food-ordering start-up, for $134 million in cash and stock. The move is a departure for Yelp, whose main business has been selling advertising bought by local businesses with those reviews. But Yelp\u2019s growth is starting to slow, and it reported a decrease in regular visitors in its most recent quarter. In a statement, Jeremy Stoppelman, Yelp\u2019s chief executive, said the purchase would help Yelp customers more easily do business with companies online. Yelp will have plenty of competitors. GrubHub, an online food ordering company and a longtime competitor of Eat24, recently acquired DiningIn and Restaurants on the Run, two delivery services that take food directly to customers who order it through the company. Yelp also faces start-ups like Postmates, which enables customers to order food from almost any restaurant for delivery, and Square, which recently bought the food delivery start-up Caviar. Bigger competitors may be coming, too. Amazon and Google have experimented with on-demand delivery services, and Uber, the ride-hailing start-up, has signaled its own ambitions of becoming a way to deliver anything to anyone. [{"abstract": "Amazon is by far the largest e-commerce player. Six hundred smaller fry gathered in Chicago this week to work out strategies for competing against or even cooperating with the Seattle giant.", "web_url": "https://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2015/06/05/selling-e-commerce-while-avoiding-amazon/", "snippet": "Amazon is by far the largest e-commerce player. Six hundred smaller fry gathered in Chicago this week to work out strategies for competing against or even cooperating with the Seattle giant.", "lead_paragraph": "For all of the noise and hype \u2014 drones! one-hour delivery! get more toilet paper painlessly! \u2014 e-commerce is showing the first signs of maturing as a business. Figures from the research firm eMarketer show the rate of domestic growth falling from 16.5 percent in 2013 to 14.2 percent this year to 11.6 percent in 2018. {"abstract": "European finance ministers are set to discuss how soon Greece receives its next disbursement of funds from the country\u2019s latest international bailout.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2015/10/05/business/finance-ministers-meet-to-discuss-greek-bailout.html", "snippet": "European finance ministers are set to discuss how soon Greece receives its next disbursement of funds from the country\u2019s latest international bailout.", "lead_paragraph": "Eurozone finance ministers are set to discuss how soon Greece receives its next disbursement of funds from the country\u2019s latest international bailout at their monthly gathering on Monday in Luxembourg. No major decisions are expected at the meeting, the first of its kind since Greek voters returned Alexis Tsipras to power as prime minister last month. But it will be an opportunity for Greece\u2019s finance minister, Euclid Tsakalotos, to reassure ministers that his country is carrying out the reforms required to continue tapping the bailout, worth up to 86 billion euros, or about $96.5 billion. On Tuesday, the ministers, joined by their counterparts from European Union countries outside the single-currency zone, will try to reach a political deal on a law forcing the bloc\u2019s 28 member states to exchange information about preferential tax agreements like those granted by Luxembourg to Amazon, and by the Netherlands to Starbucks. -James Kanter", "print_section": "B", "print_page": {"abstract": "Apple, Microsoft and Amazon will announce their quarterly reports, the Fed will gather for the first time this year, and American and European negotiators have until Sunday to reach an agreement.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2016/01/25/business/tech-giants-earnings-the-fed-meets-and-a-deadline-on-a-data-sharing-deal.html", "snippet": "Apple, Microsoft and Amazon will announce their quarterly reports, the Fed will gather for the first time this year, and American and European negotiators have until Sunday to reach an agreement.", "lead_paragraph": "This week\u2019s quarterly earnings announcements will include results from three of the technology sector\u2019s most important companies: Apple, Microsoft and Amazon. Investors on Tuesday will try to divine from Apple\u2019s numbers just how quickly the company\u2019s growth is decelerating. Their focus will be on iPhone sales. On Thursday, Microsoft and Amazon investors will want to see strong growth in both companies\u2019 computing services businesses. Although Microsoft is an important software maker and Amazon is one the world\u2019s most successful e-commerce businesses, those companies also run two of the largest cloud services companies, selling remote computing services and information storage. \u2014Katie Benner", "print_section": "B", "print_page": "2", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [{"rank": 0, "subtype": "xlarge",
